awd_titl_txt: Upgrade of Spinner Magnetometer for Continuing and New Paleomagnetic Research Objectives at Tufts University
awd_abstract_narration:
This Division of Earth Sciences Instrumentation and Facilities Program award supports acquisition of an Agico JR-6 Dual Speed Spinner Magnetometer to measure magnetism in oriented geological samples at Tufts University.  The instrument would replace a 32-year old and no longer functional magnetometer.  The magnetometer measures:  polarity, which varies between a normal polarity, like the present Earth’s field, and a reversed field in which magnetic directions are flipped 180 degrees from today’s field; magnetic declination, which is a measurement of how the field direction differs from true north; and magnetic inclination, which is the dip away from horizontal of Earth’s magnetic field direction at any given place. Time varying magnetic signature of rocks and sediments are used for correlation and age dating.  Student training in paleomagnetic methods and research applications will be advanced with the acquisition and the investigator plans local outreach through guided field trips and production of educational materials targeted at K-12 teachers and students to advance awareness of the Earth’s magnetic field and its time varying dynamic behavior.

Research projects that will immediately benefit from the new magnetometer include study of:  the chronology and spatial distribution of glacial varve deposition in New England and by inference the history and mechanisms of Quaternary glacial activity in the region; the tectonic and paleogeographic history of Neoproterozoic rocks of the Avalon terrane; the pre-Wisconsinan glacial history of New England based on determination of the chronology of  subglacial till and intra-till lake deposits.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The magnetometer funded by this grant was used for several projects at Tufts University that investigated the magnetic properties of various types of glacial sediment from the last ice age in the Connecticut Valley of New Hampshire and the Mohawk Valley region of central New York as well as rock formations dating from 100's of millions of years ago in the Middlesex Fells Reservation north of Boston, Mass.

Varved (annually-layered) glacial lake sediment from the Connecticut Valley of New Hampshire was studied to determine the precise age of the sediment and the age of deglaciation. Records of ancient magnetism (remanent magnetization) in deposits of the Cold River valley were compared to an existing record of magnetism from the Connecticut Valley. The new site added to our knowledge of the deglaciation history. For the Cold River valley deglaciation was determined to have occurred at about 15,000 years ago.

Magnetism was measured in sediment deposited beneath a glacier (till) during the last glaciation in the West Canada Valley of the western Mohawk Valley region of central New York. It was determined that magnetic directions (remanent magnetization or remanence) were stable, consistent, of normal polarity, and distinctly different from magnetic susceptibility (magnetic fabric) directions that depict the orientation of relatively coarse magnetic particles in the sediment. Remanence, which is carried by much finer particles (less than 2 microns), had a direction that was steep and not flattened during the shearing of the sediment at the time of deposition. It seems like the remanence was set mainly by alignment of very fine particles to an ancient magnetic field direction although it may have been dispersed somewhat by shearing forces. This seems to open the possibility of using till units for determining the direction of an ancient magnetic field.

Magnetic measurements from the youngest (E-W oriented) dolerite dikes in the Middlesex Fells Reservation were obtained to determine the ancient field direction at the time that these dikes were formed. So far dating of the dikes has been elusive because they do not carry zircon crystals that can be used for uranium-lead dating and argon and potassium-argon radiometric techniques are problematic in these rocks. So far, the dolerite dikes have had remanence measured after alternating field demagnetization and thermal demagnetization. The dikes have stable and consistent as well an anti-polar directions indicating that they were formed during a time of geomagnetic field reversal(s). In the past this youngest set of prominent dikes has generally been considered Mesozoic in age but because of the way the dikes are cut by several ages of faults they are likely Paleozoic. Paleomagnetism allows a test of these two ages.

An additional outcome of these projects has been the training of three undergraduate students in paleomagnetic techniques. The students carried out field sampling, sample preparation, and laboratory analyses under the direction of the PI leading to their own research projects.
